questions.text: A patient recently diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia starts fludarabine and later develops vomiting, abdominal pain, hematuria, and signs of kidney dysfunction along with electrolyte abnormalities and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. Which condition has he likely developed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and lab findings, are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome.

The patient has been started on fludarabine, a cytotoxic drug to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The cytotoxic drug causes lysis of tumor cells, leading to hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia. The uric acid crystals and calcium phosphate precipitate in the tubules and cause damage to the epithelium, subsequently causing renal failure. 

Patients with impaired renal function, high tumor burden, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level are more likely to develop tumor lysis syndrome. 

Management is by aggressive hydration and administration of allopurinol at the same time as fludarabine are used to reduce the incidence of tumor lysis syndrome. Febuxostat, a non-selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to treat hyperuricemia. It does not require dose calculations and can be used in patients with mildly decreased renal function. Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase, may also be used in patients with renal failure. Hemodialysis can be done in severe cases not responding to treatment. 

Other options:

Option B - Chronic kidney disease would have a long-term history of impaired kidney function. This patient’s kidney dysfunction is of recent onset. In addition, his laboratory values are more suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. 

Option C - Urate arthropathy (gouty arthritis) is not likely in this patient as he has no joint involvement. 

Option D - Nephrotoxic nephropathy is unlikely in this patient. Fludarabine is a purine nucleotide analog that causes myelosuppression, immunosuppression, fever, myalgia, and arthralgias.

questions.text: You are posted in your medicine ward and your consultant asks you to prescribe an ultra-short-acting insulin to a patient. Inside the drug tray, you notice the following drugs. Identify the drug that you will not give to the patient.
questions.solution:
Glargine is a long-acting insulin. Hence, it will not be given to the patient in this scenario.

Aspart, Lispro and Glulisine are all ultra-short-acting insulins.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Ultra short acting:

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting:

  • Regular

Intermediate acting:

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting:

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec

questions.text: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased in all except ___________.
questions.solution:
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased in all the given conditions except, polycythemia vera.

LAP score is characteristically increased in Leukemoid reaction and Polycythemia Vera.

Note: Leukemoid reaction: Extreme elevations in WBC counts >50,000/cu.mm due to reactive causes outside the marrow. eg. severe infection, trauma, bone marrow infiltration, Down syndrome.

Other options :

LAP score is decreased in chronic myeloid leukemia (Option A), paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (Option B) and sickle cell anemia (Option C).

Related Pearl: Leucocyte Alkaline Phosphatase Score

Aplastic anemia

Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: Examination of the oral cavity of a patient with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) revealed the findings shown in the picture below. Which of the following is the most likely subtype of AML in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely subtype of Acute Myeloid Leukemia in this patient is AML-M5. 

The picture shows swollen and spongy gums in a patient with AML. Gum infiltration is characteristic of acute monocytic leukemia (AML-M5). Infiltration of the gingivae, skin, soft tissues or meninges with leukemic blasts is characteristic of the monocytic subtypes and those with 11q23 chromosomal abnormalities. If M5 is not given in options, the next best answer would be acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4).

Other options : 

Option a : AML-M7 is associated with downs syndrome and bone marrow fibrosis.

Option c : AML-M3 is associated with DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation).

Option d : AML-M1 is associated AML without maturation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient reports decreased sensation to pain in his fingertips over the past two months, particularly when exposed to cold weather. On examination, his toes exhibit the findings shown in the image below, and his fingertips appear waxy and mottled. All of the following measures are correct regarding the management of this condition, except:

choices.text: Analgesics are often required during rewarming.
Rapid rewarming can be accomplished by immersing the foot in a warm water bath
Rubbing/friction can be used to hasten up the process of rewarming
Tetanus prophylaxis must be given as there is increased risk of tetanus in frost bite

questions.solution:
Rewarming by rubbing/ friction is not advised in the case of a frostbite.

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. The affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a warm water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 min (Option B). Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised.
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming(Option A).
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytics and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given (Option D), but empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

questions.text:
A woman presents with insidious onset, worsening exertional breathlessness, and occasional exertional chest pain. On examination, she has increased JVP, peripheral edema, ascites, and a loud P2. Her investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Chest X-ray - enlarged central pulmonary arteries and vascular pruning 

Echocardiography - hypertrophied right ventricle

ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

JVP: Jugulovenous pulse, STEMI: ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hypertension. 

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and increased vascular resistance caused by various causes. It is defined by mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20mmHg

Clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, and syncope. It is irreversible as it does not have a curative treatment and thus can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Clinical signs may include right heart failure features such as elevated JVP, edema, ascites as a result of disease progression. Chest auscultation may reveal loud P2, S3 and S4. 

Investigations of PH include: 

  • Echocardiogram with bubble study - it is an important screening test. It usually shows a dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle and increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
  • Right heart catheterization - it is the gold standard test to establish the diagnosis of PH and to select appropriate therapy.
  • Chest X-ray - may show obliteration of retrosternal space, enlarged pulmonary arteries, and peripheral vascular pruning.
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

Other options: 

Option A: Acute STEMI would reveal ST elevations in ECG. It is an acute event while this patient has had insidious onset exertional chest pain. Pain is classically described as heavy, squeezing, and crushing. Cardiac biomarkers are also raised in STEMI.

Option C: Left-sided heart failure is characterized by pulmonary edema, dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Elevated JVP, weight gain, gastrointestinal symptoms and ascites are signs of right-sided heart failure. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of sudden death in young individuals. It is characterized by exertional dyspnea, angina, left-sided congestion, and left-ventricular outflow obstruction.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with neurological symptoms (intentional tremors and poor scholastic performance) and liver disease (icterus and hepatomegaly) is suggestive of Wilson's disease. 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal-recessive condition caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes for the ATPase that removes copper, preventing its accumulation in the liver and brain. Liver disease is the most common manifestation in children which can present as hepatomegaly (cirrhosis in advanced stages) with or without splenomegaly, subacute or chronic hepatitis, and acute liver failure. Neurologic features consist of dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia. Psychiatric symptoms encompass personality changes, such as irritability and anger, as well as depression and anxiety. 

Kayser–Fleischer (KF) rings (deposition of copper in Descement's membrane) are present in 95% of patients with neurological symptoms and absent in half of the young patients with liver-related Wilson disease. After treatment KF ring resolves. Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia may also be seen. Hemolytic anemia can result from the release of copper into the circulation from the liver. Additional manifestations of Wilson's disease comprise renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis.

Diagnosis is made by the presence of a KF ring and decreased levels of serum copper and ceruloplasmin. Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion is seen. Hepatic copper content greater than 250 μg/g dry weight measured by liver biopsy is the gold standard. 

Copper intake should be restricted to <1 mg/day. Initial treatment involves copper-chelating agents D-penicillamine and trientine with concurrent use of pyridoxine. Penicillamine may worsen neurologic symptoms, so trientine is an alternative. Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate is another chelating agent being investigated for patients with neurologic disease. 

Zinc is used in presymptomatic patients due to its ability to impair the absorption of copper. Liver transplantation is considered in advanced stages. 

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It is characterized by involuntary movements known as chorea.

Option C: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive disease that manifests in the 1st year of life. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase. Clinical features are hypotonia and jitteriness at birth, progressive hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis), and may have seizures. 

Option D: Hepatitis A is a viral infection transmitted by the fecal-oral route, which is the commonest, parenteral route, and also by sexual transmission. The onset of jaundice is preceded by symptoms like nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever. Hepatitis A resolves completely but a relapse may occur in a few cases.

questions.text: A patient presented with massive abdominal swelling. Paracentesis fluid was sent for lab analysis and results show serum protein to be 3g/dL and ascitic fluid protein to be 1g/dL. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario with serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL and ascitic fluid protein <2.5 g/dL is late Budd Chiari syndrome.

Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be used to differentiate between ascites due to portal hypertension and non-portal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient.

It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin level - Ascitic fluid albumin level.

Interpretation of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

In cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites as in early Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein as in late Budd-Chiari syndrome

Other options : 

Option a : Congestive heart failure, has SAAG ≥1.1, with Ascitic protein >2.5g/dL, indicating the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites.

Option b : Early Budd-Chiari syndrome, has SAAG ≥1.1, with Ascitic protein >2.5g/dL, indicating the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites.

Option d : Tuberculosis is associated with SAAG <1.1g/dL indicating that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given condition is lupus pernio. Lupus pernio is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eyes, and skin. It is more common in women. Though Asteroid and Schaumann bodies are characteristic of sarcoidosis, they are not pathognomonic of sarcoidosis because these bodies can be seen in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis, etc.

In sarcoidosis, there is an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase due to which granulomas form in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas and are formed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells with no central necrosis, unlike tubercular granulomas.

Dermatological features include maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to chronic disease.

The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating granuloma.

Other options:

Option A- Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis. It is characterized by reddish-brown papules and slow-growing plaques with elevated borders and central atrophy as shown in the image below.

Option C- Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

The image of heliotrope rash is shown below.

Option D-  Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.

questions.text: A patient who suffered from myocardial infarction four days ago now complains of dyspnea. On auscultation, a pansystolic murmur is heard, which is loudest at the tricuspid area. Which of the following complications is likely to have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient developing pansystolic murmur which is loudest in tricuspid area, four days following a myocardial infarction, a diagnosis of ventricular septal perforation is most likely. 

Pansystolic (or holosystolic) murmurs begin with S1 and continue through systole to S2. They are usually indicative of chronic mitral or tricuspid valve regurgitation or a ventricular septal defect. Post myocardial infarction ventricular septal rupture produces a pansystolic murmur which is loudest at the mid- to lower-left sternal border and accompanied by a systolic thrill at the left sternal border. This should be differentiated from early systolic murmur, which is seen in acute mitral regurgitation which develops following papillary muscle rupture (option D). This early systolic murmur is best heard at the apical impulse.

Both ventricular septal perforation and papillary muscle rupture mostly occur in the first week following myocardial infarction. A new onset murmur in a patient with myocardial infarction is an indication for transthoracic echocardiography because it allows precise characterization of the pathology behind the murmur. 

Ventricular aneurysm (option A) occurs because of outward bulging of the ventricular wall during contraction (dyskinesia). It is not associated with any mumurs, but it can lead to the formation of mural thrombus and embolism. Ventricular free wall rupture (option B) causes cardiac tamponade and often death.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presenting with mild chest pain is admitted in the hospital. A cardiac MRI reveals the findings shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of spade-like deformity of the left ventricle in cardiac MRI points towards a diagnosis of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, also called Yamaguchi syndrome, is characterized by hypertrophy of the myocardium, predominantly in the left ventricular apex. It was first described in the Japanese population and is uncommon in other populations. The symptoms are milder and the risk of sudden cardiac death is lower than the traditional septal form of HCM. The ECG shows giant T wave inversions in apical precordial leads.

The given MRI image shows apical hypertrophy & obliteration of the LV apical cavity at end-diastole, with a typical spade-like configuration as shown below.

Other options :

Option a : Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents as acute anterior myocardial infarction, with acute chest pain or shortness of breath. It occurs soon after a high catecholamine surge and is seen predominantly in postmenopausal women.  Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronaries. The LV appears as a round ampulla, resembling the Japanese octopus pot called takotsubo pot. Imaging reveals apical left ventricular ballooning due to myocardial stunning. 

 

Option b : Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction. They often present with right-sided heart symptoms like edema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration.

Option c : Dilated cardiomyopathy presents with symptoms and signs of left heart failure or biventricular heart failure. Patients show cardiomegaly, and a third heart sound can be auscultated. The most frequent causes are alcoholism, myocarditis, chemotherapy, and endocrinopathies. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed some locally produced spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Ethanol and fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: Diazepam can be used to manage delirium tremens, or seizures due to alcohol withdrawal.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical characteristics is not associated with MEN1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma is not associated with MEN-1 syndrome. It is associated with MEN-2 syndrome.

MEN-1 or Wermer’s syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumours affecting the parathyroid gland, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. In addition, adrenocorticotropic tumours, carcinoid tumours usually of the foregut, meningiomas, facial angiofibroma, collagenomas, and lipomas may also occur in some patients with MEN1.

Other options :

Option B: Foregut carcinoid is associated with MEN-1 syndrome.

Option C: Parathyroid adenoma is associated with MEN-1 syndrome. 

Option D: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours, most commonly gastrinoma, are associated with MEN-1 syndrome.

 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero Pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – “Par Pan Pit” – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient presents with reduced urine output and is diagnosed with CKD Stage 5, requiring dialysis. During the procedure, the patient experiences an episode of hypotension. Which of the following cannot prevent dialysis-associated hypotension?

CKD-Chronic Kidney Disease
questions.solution:
Maintaining the fluid rate at > 13 mL/kg/hour will not prevent hypotension during dialysis.

The fluid rate has to be maintained at less than 13mL/kg/hour to prevent hypotension.

Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The mechanism is not fully understood and occurs due to multiple factors. However, the following precautions have been shown to frequently prevent this complication:

  • Careful calculation of the dry weight (Option B) and adjustment of the filtration rate accordingly.
  • Ultrafiltration modeling such that more fluid is removed during the beginning than at the end of the procedure.
  • Avoiding rapid fluid removal and maintaining the rate < 13 mL/kg/hour.
  • Avoiding heavy meals during dialysis (Option C).
  • Cooling of the dialysate during the dialysis (Option D)

questions.text:
Pulsus bisferiens is seen in all of the following conditions except ______

AS-Aortic stenosis

AR-Aortic regurgitation
questions.solution:
Pulsus bisferiens is seen in all the given conditions except, left ventricular dysfunction.

Pulsus bisferiens is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions :

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (Option a).
  • Aortic stenosis (AS) with Aortic regurgitation (Option b).
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option d).

Left ventricular dysfunction has pulsus alternans.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow biopsy is given below. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The biopsy image along with the clinical and peripheral smear findings are diagnostic of primary myelofibrosis.

In this condition, the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells results in increased and abnormal proliferation of the megakaryocytes. These megakaryocytes release excessive amounts of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-β. Increased growth factors lead to the deposition of collagen in the bone marrow which eventually leads to fibrosis. 

Common clinical features are :

  • Anemia- occurs as a result of decreased RBC production
  • Hepatosplenomegaly- The stem cells may escape from the marrow and get lodged in the liver and spleen leading to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
  • Peripheral smear findings:
    • myeloproliferation will result in thrombocytosis, with large and abnormal platelets, leukocytosis
    • marrow fibrosis will result in teardrop-shaped RBCs and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocyte cells into the blood).
  • Bone marrow appears hypercellular in the early course with increased cells of all the lineages. As the disease progresses, the marrow becomes hypocellular and fibrotic.

Other options:

Option A: Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation of Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. It is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which there is an accumulation of phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets in the absence of a recognizable physiologic stimulus.

Option B: Essential thrombocythemia is a neoplasm in which the body produces too many platelets, resulting in a platelet count > 4.5 lakhs/μL. It occurs due to the mutations in the JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes.Peripheral smear shows abnormally large platelets and bone marrow biopsy shows increased number of megakaryocytes, with hyperlobulated nuclei.

Option D: Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The peripheral smear findings of CML shows neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with CD4 count < 50/μL complaints of fever, weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following investigations would you order to confirm an atypical mycobacterial infection?

choices.text: Cartridge based nucleic acid amiplification test

questions.solution:
Infection with  Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is confirmed by blood culture. MAC is the atypical Mycobacterium most commonly associated with human disease. MAC is primarily a pulmonary pathogen that affects immune-compromised individuals.

MAC is an atypical mycobacterial infection commonly seen in HIV-infected patients most commonly in those with CD4 count < 50/μL, presenting with fever, weight loss and night sweats. Chest X-ray may show bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, or alveolar infiltrates and mediastinal adenopathy. Diagnosis is made by blood culture or two positive sputum cultures.

As per NACO guidelines, routine prophylaxis is not recommended in India. Therapy for MAC infection is with Clarithromycin or Azithromycin + Ethambutol. 

Other Options:

CBNAAT, IFN-𝛄 assay and BAL may all used to diagnose M. tuberculosis but are not used in the lab diagnosis of MAC. On the other hand, blood culture is not used to diagnose TB.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of central apnea?

choices.text: Transient cessation of neural drive to all respiratory muscles
Is due to decreased sensitivity to pCO2

questions.solution:
All the given statements are true about central sleep apnea except, it is due to decreased sensitivity to pCO2. It is due to increased sensitivity to pCO2.

An increase in pCO2 in normal individuals leads to reflex hyperventilation to restore the pCO2 levels to normal. But in CSA, due to increased sensitivity to pCO2 at the central respiratory center, even very mild pCO2 can cause abnormally increased hyperventilation which leads to washing off of pCO2 below normal levels, which in turn leads to apnea.

Thus changes in pCO2 levels during sleep lead to an unstable breathing pattern that manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. Therefore, a Crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern known as Cheyne-Stokes respiration is seen.

Risk factors for CSA include opioid medications and hypoxia (e.g., breathing at high altitude). In some individuals, CPAP, particularly at high pressures seems to induce central apnea; this condition is referred to as complex sleep apnea.

Other options :

Option a : CSA is associated with transient cessation of neural drive to all respiratory muscles.

Option b : CSA is associated with a Crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern known as Cheyne-Stokes respiration.

Option d : Opiod medication is a risk factor for CSA.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with steatorrhea?
questions.solution:
Short bowel syndrome is associated with steatorrhoea which is defined as excess fat in stools (>7g/day) due to poor absorption of lipids.

Short bowel syndrome refers to intractable diarrhea with malabsorption of nutrients after intestinal resection or intestinal bypass surgery leading to malnutrition. The features of short bowel syndrome usually appear when the length is less than 200 cm of the small bowel, but the length and nature of the remaining bowel are also important. The common causes of short bowel syndrome include acute mesenteric ischemia, Crohn’s disease, trauma and radiation enteritis in adults, and bowel atresia and midgut volvulus in children

The clinical features include:

  • Intractable diarrhea (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion, or unabsorbed bile salts in the colon).
  • Steatorrhea (due to the depletion of the bile salt pool), gallstones (due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts).
  • Renal stones (due to increased absorption of oxalate in the colon).
  • Peptic ulcer (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion).
  • Fat-soluble (vitamin A, D, E, and K) and B12 vitamin deficiencies.

Initial treatment priorities include repletion of fluid and electrolytes lost in severe diarrhea by initiating total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Home parenteral nutrition is the mainstay of the treatment. Long-term management involves:

  • Administration of oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts
  • Dietary fat restriction
  • Parenteral vitamin and mineral supplements
  • Proton pump inhibitors to lower gastric pH
  • Octreotide to reduce the volume of GI secretions
  • Antimotility agents such as loperamide hydrochloride to delay small-intestinal transit
  • Hormonal therapy such as growth hormone, glutamine, and GLP-2 (glucagon-like peptide-2) analog (teduglutide) are used to promote intestinal adaptation.  

 Other options:

Option B: Primary lactase deficiency leads to defective absorption of lactose. It does not affect lipid absorption.

Option C: Pernicious anemia is due to an absence of gastric parietal cell-intrinsic factor which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12

Option D: Wilsons disease is associated with increased absorption of copper and is not a part of malabsorption syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of amenorrhea, headache, vomiting, loss of libido, and galactorrhea. On examination, her vital signs are within normal limits, but her eye examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following drugs is preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of prolactinoma of the pituitary. Among the given options, cabergoline is the preferred drug for this patient.

Prolactinoma: Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumor
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. The mainstay of treatment is medical management. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. 

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. It effectively suppresses prolactin secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or along with somatostatin analogs.

Another drug used in prolactinoma is bromocriptine. It is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline. The adverse effects of bromocriptine include hypotension and nausea. 

Other options:

Option A: Thyroxine: Used for hypothyroidism, not indicated here unless there is concurrent hypothyroidism.

Option B: Estradiol: Could address hypogonadism due to elevated prolactin but does not treat the underlying prolactinoma.

Option D: Somatostatin: Used primarily for growth hormone-secreting tumors, not effective for prolactinomas.

questions.text: A 10 year old girl exhibits rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary movements. This is an example of_________.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary movements are seen in chorea.

Chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements that mainly affect the head and upper limbs. The characteristic darting movements in the tongue are visible. The choreic movements are caused by the destruction of D2 neurons of the neostriatum. The neostriatum consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen.

Hyperkinetic Movement Disorders:

Tremor

Rhythmic oscillation of a body part due to intermittent muscle contractions.

Dystonia

Involuntary, sustained or repeated muscle contractions often associated with twisting movements and abnormal posture.

Athetosis

Slow, distal, writhing, involuntary movements with a propensity to affect arms and hands.

Chorea

Rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, non patterned, involuntary movements involving distal or proximal muscle groups.

Myoclonus

Sudden, brief (<100ms), jerk-like arrhythmic muscle twitches.

Tics

Brief, repeated, stereotyped muscle contractions that can often be suppressed for a short time.

 

Other options :

Option A: Tremor is rhythmic oscillation of a body part due to intermittent muscle contractions.

Option B: Myoclonus is sudden, brief (<100ms), jerk-like arrhythmic muscle twitches.

Option D: Athetosis is slow, distal, writhing, involuntary movements with a propensity to affect arms and hands.

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

 

 Movement Site Discription Cause

  • Trauma
  • Stroke
  • Alcohol
  • Drugs
Resting tremor

Substantia nigra

Red nucleus

 Disappear on movement
  •  Parkinsonism
Hyperkinetic tremor Sympathetic overactivity  Precipitated by emotion , stress
  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism

  • Hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: An IT professional diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency during a routine check-up began taking 60,000 IU vitamin D sachets daily. Two weeks later, he presented with severe colicky pain in the renal angle. His vitamin D levels are elevated (170 ng/mL). Which medication would be helpful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts vitamin D toxicity and calcitonin can be used in the treatment of this condition.

Vitamin D toxicity occurs due to excessive intake of vitamin D supplements, usually in amounts of >40,000–100,000 IU/day. The symptoms are mainly due to hypercalcemia. Laboratory investigations will show elevated serum vitamin D levels (>100 ng/mL) and calcium.

In such patients, vitamin D supplements should be discontinued immediately, along with restricted exposure to the sun and avoiding calcium supplements. Since vitamin D is stored in the body for a long time, the symptoms may persist for some days even after stopping the intake.

Calcitonin and bisphosphonates are used in cases of severe toxicity causing hypercalcemia. Some patients might require glucocorticoids, which lower plasma calcium levels by reducing calcium absorption from the intestines and increasing its urinary excretion. 

Other options

Option B- Aspirin is used in the management of niacin-induced flushing.

Options C and D- Trientine and zinc are copper chelators. They are mainly used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of asthma, complaints of pain and numbness in both legs. Examination findings include palpable purpura and asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex. Peripheral blood smear findings show eosinophila. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangitis).

It is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and in order to be diagnosed with Churg-Strauss, a patient should have evidence of asthma, peripheral blood and tissue eosinophilia (>1000 cells/μL), extravascular granuloma formation and clinical features consistent with vasculitis. 

Common presenting symptoms of this condition are lower respiratory tract symptoms such as severe attacks of asthma, upper respiratory tract symptoms such as allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, and nasal polyps, mono neuritis multiplex (a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves) which presents with a complaint of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas and skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules. P-ANCA antibodies are present in Churg Strauss syndrome. 

Glucocorticoids show effective responses in these patients. Other drugs that have been tried are mepolizumab and rituximab. For fulminant multisystem disease, daily cyclophosphamide with prednisolone followed by azathioprine or methotrexate is used.

Other options:

Option A: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but they do not have eosinophilia.

Option D: Giant cell arteritis manifests with the cardinal symptom of headache localized to the temporal region.

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

Predominant vessel involved

Inflammatory cells

Other features

Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Microscopic polyangiitis

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: A 25 year old female came with complaints of fatigue and neck swelling since past 4 months. She delivered a baby 4 months ago and is currently breastfeeding her child. Lab investigations reveal elevated serum TSH with normal T3,T4 levels. Physical examination shows slight enlargement of thyroid gland but everything else is normal. All the following are true regarding the given condition except?

choices.text: It is associated with Type 1 diabetes
Thyroxine replacement therapy is given life long
It is associated with transient production of anti thyroid antibodies
Follow up with TSH is done after 2 month

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a postpartum female with painless neck swelling points towards diagnosis of Postpartum thyroiditis and lifelong thyroxine replacement therapy is NOT necessary in management of this condition. The next step in management is to reassure her and do a follow-up TSH 2 months later.

Postpartum thyroiditis is a subset of silent thyroiditis. It is specifically used to describe the constellation of symptoms of silent thyroiditis in a postpartum patient 3-6 months after birth. It occurs due to the transient production of anti-thyroid antibodies during periods of stress (Option C). The condition is observed in up to 5% of women and it is 3 times more common in women with type 1 diabetes mellitus. (Option A)

Typically, patients experience a brief phase of thyrotoxicosis lasting 2-4 weeks, followed by hypothyroidism for 4-12 weeks, and then clinical resolution. Often, only one phase is apparent. Subacute thyroiditis often has a normal ESR value and TPO antibodies. 

Severe thyrotoxic symptoms can be managed with a brief course of propranolol, a 20–40 mg dose administered three or four times daily.

Thyroxine replacement may be needed for treating the hypothyroid phase but should be withdrawn after 6–9 months, to enable patient recovery. This patient with mild symptoms of hypothyroidism should be managed expectantly. Patients should be followed up every 2 months with TSH measures to check for symptom resolution and analyze the need for hormone supplementation. (Option D)

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the OPD with mild fever since 12 days, non-productive cough, headache, and neck rigidity. The patient also complained of multiple joint pains. A chest x-ray was done which shows interstitial infiltration. Which is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with chest X-ray showing interstitial infiltration along with patchy consolidation at hilum and fanning to the periphery is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma.

Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia. Clinically it has an insidious onset, non-productive cough, and milder fever compared to typical pneumonia. URTI (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) is a common pulmonary manifestation.

It is often associated with extrapulmonary manifestations. Extrapulmonary manifestations include neurologic manifestations like encephalitis or aseptic meningitis (as seen in this patient), cold agglutinin disease (IgM mediated AIHA), Erythema multiforme or SJS, arthralgia with adenopathy, Guillain barre syndrome, myocarditis, pericarditis, encephalitis, and bullous myringitis. 

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays. Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

The chest X-ray showing interstitial infiltration along with patchy consolidation at hilum and fanning to the periphery is shown in the image below.

Other options :

Option a : Pneumococci are commensals of the upper respiratory tract and can cause pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis, bronchitis, bacteremia, meningitis, peritonitis, and other infectious processes.The onset of pneumococcal pneumonia is usually sudden, with fever, chills, and sharp pleural pain. The sputum is similar to the alveolar exudate, being characteristically bloody or rusty colored. Disseminated infection and bacteremia can present as meningitis, endocarditis, and septic arthritis.

Option c : Legionella pneumophila is a fastidious, aerobic gram-negative coccobacillus. It can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements. Diagnosis is by the identification of legionella antigens in urine by latex agglutination or Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA). Treatment is by newer macrolides, ciprofloxacin or tetracycline. Aminoglycoside and beta lactam antibiotics are ineffective. 

Option d :  Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters. It is coagulase and catalase positive. It causes bacterial pneumonia with features similar to pneumococcal pneumonia. The differentiating feature is that chest X-ray in Staph. aureus infection shows pneumatoceles (cavitation).

The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma).
 

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.

 

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-
    • Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)
    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to the physician after an episode of hemoptysis. She has a history of a non-productive cough for the past 3 months and reports a weight loss of 5 kilograms over the past month. She does not smoke. A chest X-ray reveals a 2.8 cm irregular nodule in the left lung, and CT findings are provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with CT findings showing irregular lesion at the periphery of the lung with no hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of lung.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common tumor of the lung in non-smokers. It is more common in women. Adenocarcinoma of the lung occurs in the periphery of the lung, frequently in areas of chronic scarring caused by chronic inflammatory changes. EGFR oncogene mutations are common in adenocarcinomas of non-smokers. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and symptoms due to metastasis. Some are responsible for paraneoplastic syndromes.

Lung adenocarcinomas are now classified by their predominant pattern: 

  • Lepidic pattern (best prognosis; tumors ≤3 cm or with ≤5 mm invasion has near 100% 5-year disease-free survival with complete tumor resection).
  • Acinar pattern.
  • Papillary pattern.
  • Solid patterns (poor prognosis).

Lung nodules should always be compared with previous films. A CT scan is done for further evaluation and a biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.The CT findings showing irregular lesion at the periphery of the lung with no hilar lymphadenopathy is shown below.

 

Other options :

Option a : Squamous cell cancer most commonly occurs in smokers and is typically centrally located.

Option c : Small cell cancer is a highly aggressive cancer that metastasizes early. It is also often associated with smoking and is generally metastasized by the time it gets diagnosed.

Option d : Sarcoidosis can present with weight loss and non-productive cough. However, there is associated hilar lymphadenopathy, which is absent in this patient. 

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with alcohol addiction presents with loss of appetite, jaundice, and easy bruisability. The following abnormality is noted on examination. This nail change occurs due to:
questions.solution:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia totalis and it occurs due to hypoalbuminemia.

 Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discoloration of the nail. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of liver cirrhosis which is one of the causes of leukonychia.

Leukonychia is seen in the following conditions :

  • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency.
  • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine.
  • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiforme, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE.
  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure.
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride) and idiopathic condition.

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines, as shown in the image below.

Other options :

Option a : Inflammatory bowel disease is associated with clubbing.

Option c : Chronic iron deficiency is associated with Koilonychia.

Option d : Hyperthyroidism is associated with oncholysis.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The disease pathogenesis primarily involving the marked structure is Parkinson's diease. The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

The image below is the cross section at the level of superior colliculus showing absent or reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Other options :

Option b : Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

Option c : Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe.

Option d : Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

questions.text: Identify the tachycardia depicted in the given ECG.
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves (red arrows), known as flutter waves. Hence, it is most likely to be atrial flutter.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. As the atrial rate is around 300 bpm, AV conduction ratio of 2:1 results in a ventricular rate of ~150 bpm.

Other options :

Option a : Atrial fibrillation rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, characteristic of atrial fibrillation, as shown in the ECG below.

Option c : Ventricular tachycardia ecg changes include wide QRS complexes, absence of P waves, and ventriculoatrial dissociation. In monomorphic VT, all QRS complexes look the same. Polymorphic VT has QRS complexes varying in shape or direction in the same lead.

The ecg of ventricular tachycardia is given below.

Option d : Ventricular fibrillation shows a completely disorganized rhythm with no identifiable waves on ECG, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A diagnosis of gouty arthritis is made after aspiration of the synovial fluid and polarised light microscopy shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals as shown in the image given below.  These crystals are suggestive of.
questions.solution:
Negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals seen on polarised light microscopy in gouty arthritis is due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals.

The  polarised light microscopic findings showing monosodium urate crystals is given below.,

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can accumulate in areas of tissue damage, hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states.

Option C- Calcium Oxalate crystals are seen in chronic renal failure.

Option D- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are rhomboid-shaped and are seen in pseudogout, as shown in image below.

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria.  Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It results from immune complex deposition containing DNA and anti-DNA. Clinical features include proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. The disease is divided into 6 classes based on the severity. Patients with class V disease are at an increased risk of thrombotic complications. Lupus nephritis can result in end-stage disease warranting dialysis or transplantation.

SLE is an autoimmune condition more commonly seen in women. Antinuclear antibodies, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Sm are the autoantibodies implicated. Symptoms include maculopapular butterfly rash, photosensitivity, oral or nasal ulcers, fever, and intermittent polyarthritis. Pleuritis and pericarditis can also be associated. Systemic glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide, or mycophenolate mofetil are used for management. Due to the possible teratogenic effects of these drugs, hydroxychloroquine is the mainstay in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A - Acute interstitial nephritis is a type of acute kidney injury. It is marked by oliguria and raised creatinine. Various causes of interstitial injury include the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), pyelonephritis, leukemia, and sepsis. White blood cell (WBC) casts and granular casts may be seen.

Option B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis usually affects male children between the age of 2-14. Skin or pharyngeal infection with M types of the organism is implicated. Symptoms include hematuria, pyuria, and hypertension. Flank pain and headache are also associated symptoms. Red blood cell (RBC) casts are seen in the urine.

Option D - IgA nephropathy arises due to mesangial IgA deposition. It is characterized by recurrent macroscopic hematuria after an upper respiratory infection associated with proteinuria. Mesangial proliferation is a distinctive feature. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and steroids can be used for management.

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin. Investigations revealed markedly elevated direct bilirubin levels. Which of the following conditions should be suspected in the newborn?
questions.solution:
The raised direct bilirubin levels indicate conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which is suggestive of biliary atresia.

Biliary atresia is the disorder that causes destruction or absence of bile ducts in a newborn. It leads to obstruction to the flow of bile thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation. It may also be termed as noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology.

The classification of biliary atresia with the regions involved is as follows:

  • Type I - Common bile duct.
  • Type IIa - Common hepatic duct.
  • Type IIb - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct.
  • Type III (most common type) - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct; no anastomosable ducts at porta hepatis.

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive).

Laboratory evaluation will show elevated levels of direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and the triangular cord sign, hyperechoic structure at porta hepatitis. The definitive diagnosis is by intraoperative cholangiography. Preoperative percutaneous transhepatic cholecystocholangiography combined with liver biopsy in cholestatic infants has a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 93% for diagnosing biliary atresia. Treatment is surgery via roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy for type I and Kasai procedure or liver transplantation for type II and III.

Other options :

Option b : Physiological jaundice of the newborn is because of the immature liver of the newborn that is not able to conjugate the excess bilirubin produced after birth. It leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option c : Breast milk Jaundice , is associated with breast milk which may contain certain factors that inhibit the conjugation of bilirubin leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option d : Hemolytic disease of the newborn causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia because of the excess production of bilirubin due to hemolysis.

questions.text: Mr.Rajesh comes with complaints of non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality on both sides of his forehead. He describes it as wearing a tight cap. He has no nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia.  All of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this condition except
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension type headache and sumatriptan is not useful in treatment of this condition.

Tension-type headache(TTH) is commonly used to describe a chronic head-pain syndrome characterized by bilateral tight, band-like discomfort. The pain typically builds slowly, fluctuates in severity, and may persist more or less continuously for many days.

The headache may be episodic or chronic (present >15 days per month). A useful clinical approach is to diagnose TTH in patients whose headaches are complete without accompanying features such as nausea, vomiting, photophobia, phonophobia, osmophobia, throbbing, and aggravation with movement.

Treatment of TTH includes simple analgesics such as NSAIDs and paracetamol. Amitriptyline has been found to be useful for chronic TTH. Triptans are not useful in the treatment of this condition. 

Types of headache and there treatment is given in the below table.

  Tension-type headache Migraine  Cluster headache

Acute treatment

Aspirin

NSAIDs

Acetaminophen

NSAIDs

Triptans

Dihydroergotamine

100% oxygen

Sumatriptan

 
Preventive Amitriptyline  
  • Lifestyle changes(eg, sleep,exercise, diet)
  • β-blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Amitriptyline, topiramate, valproate
  • CGRP antagonists - erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab, Eptinezumab
 Verapamil 

Other options : 

Option a : Aspirin is used in treatment of tension type headache.

Option c : Acetaminophen is used in treatment of tension type headache.

Option d : Verapamil is a CCB (Calcium channel blocker), used in prevention of cluster headache.

questions.text: A patient presenting in mid-60s with vertical gaze palsy and early falls as well as the following picture on MRI, most likely has _______
questions.solution:
The clinical features of this patient combined with the MRI findings are suggestive of progressive supranuclear palsy. 

Progressive supranuclear palsy is also known as Steele–Richardson–Olszewski syndrome. It is characterized by slow ocular Saccades, eyelid apraxia and restricted eye movements. Downward gaze is predominantly impaired. Early gait disturbance and falls are seen.

The given MRI images (midsagittal) show hummingbird sign. It occurs due to characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with relative preservation of the pons. 

Other options :

Option a : Corticobasilar Ganglionic degeneration(CGBD) is an extremely rare neurodegenerative disease that is categorized under both Parkinsonian syndromes and frontal lobe dementias. It is characterized by parkinson's like motor symptoms and by deficits of movement and cognition, indicating focal brain pathology. Neuronal cell loss is ultimately responsible for the neurological symptoms. This patient’s gaze palsy makes PSP more likely.

Option b : Parinaud's syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder. Here there is a loss of up-gaze and the downward gaze is usually preserved. Parinaud's syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis. This patient has increased falls and Parkinson-like features non-responsive to L-dopa, which makes PSP more likely.

Option c : Weber's syndrome is due to the involvement of the posterior cerebral artery. It affects the cranial nerve III, ventral midbrain, and corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiplegia and contralateral paralysis of the lower part of the face. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy where the eyeball is deviated laterally because of the paralysis of the medial rectus muscle, and drooping of the upper lid (ptosis).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man who underwent coronary stenting for an acute STEMI presents at a follow-up visit with pain in his toes and discoloration of both feet, as shown in the image. His creatinine levels are also elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atheroembolism. It is also called cholesterol embolism or blue toe syndrome.

Atheroembolism is a condition in which multiple small deposits of fibrin, platelets, and cholesterol debris embolize from proximal atherosclerotic lesions or aneurysmal sites. 

The typical presentation is a patient with ST-elevation myocardial infarction presenting with features of limb ischemia (cyanotic discoloration of the toes with pain and tenderness) following an intraarterial procedure (angioplasty).

Digital vascular occlusion may result in ischemia and the "blue toe" syndrome; digital necrosis and gangrene may develop. Localized areas of tenderness, pallor, and livedo reticularis occur at sites of emboli. Since the atheroemboli tend to lodge in the small vessels of the limbs and may not occlude the large vessels, distal pulses are usually palpable.

Large protruding aortic atheromas are a source of emboli that may lead to limb ischemia, as well as stroke and renal insufficiency. Skin or muscle biopsy may demonstrate cholesterol crystals.

Other options :

Option a : Sharp syndrome, also known as mixed connective tissue disease, is an autoimmune condition with features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Clinical features include Raynaud's syndrome, polyarthritis, myositis, swollen hands, and fingers.

Option b : Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may either be primary or secondary to other autoimmune diseases, mainly SLE (secondary). The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia.

Option c : Aortic dissection results from a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta and is associated with risk factors such as age, hypertension, pregnancy, and cocaine use. Patients typically present with severe tearing chest or interscapular pain. Contrast-enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) is the preferred imaging modality for stable patients, whereas transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for unstable patients.

questions.text: A 39-year-old asthma patient presents with a cough with brownish sputum and is not responding to his regular asthma treatment. He shows elevated IgE levels and significant peripheral eosinophilia. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the chest radiograph showing the characteristic finger-in-glove sign, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). 

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to colonization of the airways by Aspergillus fumigatus. The risk factors predisposing to ABPA include asthma and cystic fibrosis. There is an obstruction of the bronchioles due to the inflammatory secretions, leading to breathlessness, coughing, and brown sputum casts.

The total circulating IgE and Aspergillus-specific IgE is elevated and there is peripheral eosinophilia. Chest radiograph may show central bronchiectasis and finger-in-glove sign due to mucous impaction in the airways. The treatment of ABPA is with itraconazole and glucocorticoids.

Other options: 

Option B: Loffler syndrome refers to transient pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia that occurs in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs, most commonly larvae of Ascaris species.

Option C: Bronchiectasis is characterized by irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles. Patients have recurrent episodes of cough with copious amounts of sputum, often foul-smelling. Radiographic features include:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest radiograph
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen
  • A signet ring sign is seen when the diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery in a cross-section, as shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs due to the inflammatory response to the microfilariae. The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheezing and cough.

questions.text: The chief mediator of anemia of chronic disease is ____.
questions.solution:
The chief mediator of anemia of chronic disease is hepcidin.

Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies. 

Hepcidin is a positive acute-phase reactant that increases in chronic inflammatory states. It binds with ferroportin which results in both reduced iron intake in the gut and reduced iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. Hence, hepcidin is a negative regulator of iron balance.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop:
questions.solution:
The pathology associated with given flow volume loop is fixed central airway obstruction.

The given flow-volume curve shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs. The curve denotes airflow limitation during both inspiration and expiration. Examples of fixed central airway obstruction include tracheal stenosis (caused by intubation) and circular tracheal tumors.

Other options:

Option A: The image given below shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb (scooped-out or coved) pattern seen in lower airway obstruction. Examples include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchiectasis, and bronchiolitis.

Option C: The image below shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in variable, nonfixed intrathoracic obstruction.

Examples: intrathoracic airway, bronchogenic cysts, or tracheal lesions.

Option D: The image below shows airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in nonfixed variable extrathoracic obstruction.

Examples: vocal cord paralysis, extrathoracic tracheomalacia, polychondritis, etc.

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: In asterixis, which of the following would commonly be seen?
questions.solution:
In asterixis, the condition commonly seen is hypercarbia. Asterixis is frequently observed in patients with hypercarbia, especially in the setting of respiratory failure or COPD, due to its effects on the central nervous system. Therefore, hypercarbia is the most appropriate option among the choices provided.

Other options:

Hypoxia refers to a condition in which there is a deficiency of oxygen reaching the tissues. While hypoxia can lead to various neurological manifestations, asterixis is not typically associated with hypoxia. Asterixis is more commonly observed in conditions affecting the central nervous system or metabolic disturbances.

Thyrotoxicosis is a condition characterized by excessive thyroid hormone levels in the bloodstream, often due to an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Asterixis is not a characteristic feature of thyrotoxicosis. Instead, thyrotoxicosis may present with symptoms such as palpitations, heat intolerance, weight loss, and tremors.

Anxiety neurosis, or anxiety disorder, refers to a group of mental health disorders characterized by excessive worry, fear, and nervousness. Asterixis is not typically associated with anxiety neurosis. While anxiety disorders can manifest with various physical symptoms, asterixis is more commonly observed in neurological or metabolic conditions.

questions.text: An intern has a needle-prick injury while establishing an IV line on a patient in the casualty. If the intern were to get infected with hepatitis B, what is the first marker to rise in an acute infection?
questions.solution:
The first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg. HBsAg is the surface antigen of the hepatitis B virus (HBV). 

It is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks. Usually, HBsAg levels go down in 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice. If it persists beyond 6 months, it indicates chronic hepatitis. 

Other options :

Option A: Anti HBs is positive if the patient is recovering from hepatitis B infection or in case of immunisation.

Option C: The presence of HBeAg indicates active replication of HBV. Therefore, HBeAg is the qualitative marker of infectivity.

Option D: The most reliable indicator of recent HBV infection is IgM anti-HBc in serum. It is demonstrable in the serum about 1-2 weeks after the appearance of HBsAg, and may sometimes persist in the serum even longer than Anti-HBs antibody.

 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

  HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc

+

Acute HBV-Window period

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

HBV infection in the remote past

Recovery - + - +/- IgG

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with a known history of CKD presents with symptoms of dehydration, thirst, anorexia, and hypotonia. After further evaluation, he is diagnosed with type 1 RTA. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of type 1 RTA?

CKD-Chronic kidney disease

RTA-Renal tubular acidosis

choices.text: Urinary pH after acid loading is <5.5

questions.solution:
Urinary pH after acid loading is <5.5 is not a feature of type-1 RTA.

In RTA type I, there is defect in DCT(distal convoluted tubule) which is a site of acidification of urine, therefore minimum pH after acid loading will always be more than 5.5.

Due to defective DCT, there is bicarbonaturia but fractional excretion of HCO3- is less than 10-15 % ( less than RTA type II). The loss of HCO3- creates negative charge in lumen of tubules and to maintain electroneutrality more potassium ion (a positive charge) is secreted in DCT, therefore leading to hypokalemia (Option a).

Hypercalciuria which occurs because of metabolic acidosis (as it causes bone resorption leading to hypercalcemia and then hypercalciuria) causes renal rickets (Option b).

Co-existance of hypercalciuria and hypocitraturia (beacuse of increased cell citrate utilization followed by intracellular acidosis) leads to Nephrocalcinosis (Option d).

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in both upper limbs. An MRI is done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing a hyperintense area in the spinal cord is syringomyelia. 

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' as it affects the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity, weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. 

There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. 

Other options: 

Option A: Spinal epidural abscess presents with fever, pain, and progressive weakness. The pain may be radicular. There would be elevated white cell count and inflammatory markers. The image below shows a spinal epidural abscess compressing the spinal cord. 

 

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Patients present with paresthesias in the hands and feet and progressive ataxic weakness. They would be areflexic due to peripheral neuropathy. The image below shows a hyperintensity in the posterior part of the spinal cord due to the involvement of the posterior columns. 

Option D: Spinal cord infarction occurs due to infarction of one of the three arteries (anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries.) Infarction of the anterior spinal artery leads to quadriplegia or paraplegia, loss of pain and temperature, and sparing of vibration and position sense. Posterior spinal artery involvement leads to a loss of posterior column functions.
