questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is produced by adipocytes?
questions.solution:
The cytokines produced by adipocytes include all the following, tumor necrosis factor alpha, interleukin-6, plasminogen activator inhibitor-1.

Although adipocytes have been regarded as storage depot of fats in general, they are also considered as endocrine cells that release numerous molecules in a regulated manner, as given in the image below.

questions.text: The lymph node biopsy of a 49-year-old woman with painless lymphadenopathy revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological finding is of lacunar Reed-Sternberg (RS cell) cell, which is seen in Nodular Sclerosis classical Hodgkin's disease.

Reed-Sternberg cell, lacunar variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within an open space, which is an artifact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning.

Histological subtypes of Classic Hodgkin's disease

Subtype Histopathology Clinical correlation
Nodular Sclerosis
  • Lacunar RS cell + necrosis +inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells
  • Fibrous bands dividing cellular areas into nodules
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and superior vena cava syndrome 
  • Excellent prognosis
Mixed cellularity Diagnostic RS cells with rich inflammatory infiltrate
  • Biphasic: Children and elderly
  • B symptoms
  • Associated with EBV (and HIV),
  • Very good prognosis
Lymphocyte-rich Background infiltrate rich
in T lymphocytes		  
Lymphocyte- depleted Reticular variant, paucity of background reactive cells
  • Associated with HIV (and EBV)
  • Poor prognosis

 

Other options :

Option a : Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's disease, has Reticular variant of RS cell. It is associated with HIV and EBV. It has poor prognosis.

Option b : Lymphocyte-rich Hodgkin's disease, is a rare subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) characterized by a small number of Hodgkin/Reed-Sternberg (HRS) cells and a background of small lymphocytes

questions.text: A 20-year-old IV drug user presents with fever. On examination, his temperature is 38.5°C, and fundoscopic examination reveals spots over the fundus. Laboratory investigations show a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm, and blood cultures have been sent. Infective endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's criteria are fulfilled in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is an intravenous drug user, with a fever of 38.5°C and spots on the fundus, indicating immunologic phenomena has 3 minor Duke's criteria.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

  • Two major criteria, or
  • One major and three minor criteria, or
  • Five minor criteria.

Note: There has been a recent update in the modified Duke's criteria, which is given in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: All of the following are the absolute contraindications of the liver transplantation except:
questions.solution:
Portal vein thrombosis is not an absolute contraindication to liver transplantation. 

Absolute contraindications of liver transplantation are:

  • Uncontrolled extra-hepatobiliary infection or untreated sepsis.
  • Uncorrectable life-limiting congenital anomalies.
  • Active substance or alcohol abuse (Option b).
  • Malignancies - Hepatocellular carcinoma with metastatic spread (Option c), incurable malignancies outside the liver, cholangiocarcinoma
  • AIDS (Option a).
  • Advanced cardiopulmonary disease.

Note - Patients with primary hepatocellular malignancy can be considered for liver transplantation if there is a single lesion ≤5 cm or up to three separate lesions all <3 cm without any evidence of gross vascular invasion, nodal or distant metastases (Milan criteria).

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presented to the emergency room within two hours of sudden onset of weakness of the right side. On examination, she had global aphasia, right facial droop, and right hemiplegia. CT angiography showed a left middle cerebral artery occlusion. Which of the following is the next best management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with CT angiography showing a left middle cerebral artery occlusion is suggestive of ischemic stroke and the next best step of management is intravenous thrombolysis.

Treatment of acute ischemic stroke:

Initial treatment: Check for the patient's pulse rate, blood pressure, temperature, and glucose levels. Treat hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever if present. Maintain the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation.

Blood pressure should be reduced acutely if :

  • Blood pressure > 220/120 mmHg.
  • There is malignant hypertension.
  • There is concomitant myocardial ischemia.
  • Blood pressure is > 185/110 mmHg and the patient is being planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Serum glucose should be maintained between 180mg/dL and 60mg/dL. Ischemia can result in edema which peaks on the second or third day and can lead to a mass effect for around 10 days. Therefore, intravenous mannitol should be started and water restriction should be advised for the patients.

Specific measures:

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 325 mg should be started within 24-48 hours of acute ischemic stroke. It is also continued as an adjunct therapy after intravenous thrombolysis.

Routine use of heparin and other oral anticoagulants is not recommended in patients with ischemic stroke because they can increase the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. They can be used if the patient is bedridden, in order to prevent deep vein thrombosis. (Option B)

 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A patient with a short PR interval and delta wave on ECG presents to the emergency department with atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular rate. He is hemodynamically stable.  All of the following drugs can be used in the management except ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of wolf parkinson syndrome and all the following drugs can be used in the management of WPW syndrome with Atrial fibrillation except Verapamil.

Rate-slowing drugs such as non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, verapamil, diltiazem), beta-blockers and digoxin are contraindicated in these patients. They increase the refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.

The drugs of choice are antiarrhythmic drugs, procainamide (Class 1a), ibutilide (class III), or amiodarone that prolong the refractory period of the accessory pathway.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the treatment of choice is direct-current cardioversion. 

The ECG below shows a short PR interval (<120 ms) and delta waves in WPW syndrome. 

 

Other options :

Option a : Amiodarone is a class III anti-arrythmic drug used in management of WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation.

Option b : Ibutilide is class III anti-arrythmic drug used in management of WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation.

Option c : Procainamide is class Ia anti-arrythmic drug used in management of WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation.

 

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: In Addison’s disease, the most commonly implemented test for clinical diagnosis is

choices.text: Serum Na+, K+, Saline Suppression Test

questions.solution:
The commonly implemented method of diagnosis of Addissons disease (adrenal insufficiency) is the ACTH Stimulation Test.

Adrenal insufficiency is the decreased production of adrenocortical hormones and is classified as primary or secondary. Evaluation of adrenal insufficiency begins with clinical suspicion based on symptoms such as weight loss, fatigue, postural hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and hyponatremia.

Diagnosis is confirmed with a cosyntropin stimulation test, which measures the adrenal glands response to synthetic ACTH (cosyntropin). A baseline cortisol level is obtained, followed by cosyntropin administration, with cortisol levels measured again after 30-60 minutes. In adrenal insufficiency, cortisol levels remain low despite stimulation.

Differentiation between primary and secondary causes involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. High ACTH levels indicate primary adrenal insufficiency, warranting adrenal autoantibody tests and further imaging like chest X-ray or adrenal CT to determine the cause. Low or normal ACTH levels indicate secondary adrenal insufficiency, necessitating an MRI of the pituitary to identify possible lesions or other underlying causes (in patients not taking corticosteroids).

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of a 47-year-old diabetic patient revealed the following values: pH- 7.2 and HCO3- 15 mEq/L. Which of the following statements is false regarding renal compensation in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the ABG analysis report is suggestive of metabolic acidosis and the false statement regarding the renal compensation in this patient is bicarbonate reabsorption is decreased. 

The ABG analysis report for the patient shows a pH of 7.2 and HCO3- level of 15 mEq/L, indicating a low pH (below the normal range of 7.35-7.45) and decreased plasma bicarbonate (below the normal range of 22-28 mEq/L), which suggests metabolic acidosis. In response, the kidneys increase bicarbonate reabsorption as a compensatory mechanism for the acidosis.

In metabolic acidosis, the kidney performs the following compensatory mechanisms in order to bring back the pH to the normal range (the aim is to increase the acidity in urine and lower the acidity in the blood):

  • The proximal tubule reabsorbs all the filtered HCO3- (as any loss of HCO3- is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of H+).
  • The collecting duct excretes the daily H+ load (loss of H+ is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of HCO3-) primarily in the form of urinary ammonia.

Other options : 

Option a : Hydrogen ion secretion is increased by collecting duct , because loss of H+ is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of bicarbonate.

Option c : Urine acidity is increased because of excretion of H+ ions.

Option d : Urine ammonia is increased because the collecting duct excretes the daily H+ load, primarily in the form of urinary ammonia.
 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 8 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg
